filedesc.updatestmt:
The William Blake Archive http://www.blakearchive.org is pleased to announce the publication of new electronic editions of Copies B and U of Blake's Songs of Innocence .
Copies B and U are a study in contrasts, yet both are from the earliest printings of this book. Copy B, now in the Rosenwald Collection, Library of Congress, was printed with fifteen other copies of Innocence in 1789, four of which were later joined with Experience impressions, printed in 1794, to form Songs of Innocence and of Experience Copies B, C—which is in the Archive—D, and E. Unlike many of these early copies of Innocence , Copy B still consists of all 31 plates originally composed and executed for Innocence . Like them, however, it was printed in a raw sienna ink on 17 leaves and exemplifies Blake's early printing and coloring style. The plates were wiped of their plate borders, the illustrations very lightly washed in watercolors, and the texts left unwashed. This mode of presentation, along with printing both sides of the leaves to create facing pages, emphasized the prints as book pages rather than prints or paintings. Good examples of printing and coloring illuminated plates to look like minatures can be seen in Songs Copy Z, also in the Archive.
Innocence Copy U, from the Houghton Library, Harvard University, is an excellent example of printing illuminated plates to look like prints. Like etchings and engravings, they were printed on one side of the leaf in black ink and left uncolored. Copy U, which was printed with untraced Copy V, had been dated c. 1814, because of some stylistic similarities it shares with illuminated works assumed to have been produced around that time. But, in fact, Copy U is the first copy of Innocence printed. The presence of a unique first state for "Infant Joy" proves this sequence; the bottom part of the "J" in the title is missing in all extant impressions, but here it extends into the flower. Copy U was printed before Copy B and all other early copies; the ink color, printing style (recto only), and lack of hand coloring suggest a date of printing before Blake had developed his special ways of producing his illuminated books and instead repeated styles and techniques long familiar to him as a commercial engraver.
Both electronic editions have newly edited SGML-encoded texts and new images scanned and color-corrected from first-generation 4x5" transparencies; they are each fully searchable for both text and images and supported by the Inote and ImageSizer applications described in our previous updates.
With the publication of these two titles, the Archive now contains 35 copies of 18 separate books, including at least one copy of every one of Blake's works in illuminated printing except the 100 plates of Jerusalem (forthcoming).

objdescid.origination: William Blake author, inventor, delineator, etcher, printer

imprint.pubplace: London The place of publication is not recorded in the volume, but Blake was living in London at the time of its composition, etching, and printing.

objinfo.printdate: 1789This is probably the first copy of *Songs of Innocence* Blake printed.
objinfo.numberobj: 31 Bentley pages 366 and 399 records an additional impression of Bentley's Plate 9 (designated "9b"), the first plate of "The Little Black Boy," in Copy U. This posthumous impression, clearly not part of the book as originally collated by Blake, is no longer with the plates in Copy U and is not included here.
objinfo.objorder: Bentley Plates 3, 2, 4, 6, 7, 9-11, 24, 15, 12, 25, 8, 13, 14, 20, 21, 53, 27, 16-19, 22, 23, 54, 26, 5, 34-36.The Houghton Library has arranged the unbound plates in this order, following plate numbers written in pencil, top right on each leaf. These numbers are not by Blake and are not shown here. They probably record the binding order established c. 1818 (see Binding, below), although this is not necessarily the original sequence established by Blake or his wife Catherine. This is also the arrangement of the plates reproduced from Copy U in *Songs of Innocence[.] William Blake[.] Reproduced by Photography from a Perfect Black and White copy of the Original Issue of 1789* (Boston: Little, Brown & Co., 1883), and the sequence recorded in Geoffrey Keynes and Edwin Wolf 2nd, *William Blake's Illuminated Books: A Census* (New York: Grolier Club, 1953) 17. Bentley page 377 records a different order: Bentley Plates 3, 2, 4, 6, 7, 9b [no longer present in Copy U], 9-12, 15, 8, 53, 24, 13, 14, 20, 21, 19, 26, 16, 17, 25, 54, 22, 23, 5, 27, 18, 34-36. In footnote 5 on page 377, Bentley states that this order "derives from the pencil numbers confirmed by the offsets," but this is not the case.
objinfo.objsize: ranging between 12.3 x 7.7 cm. and 10.9 x 6.3 cm.
objinfo.medium: relief etching with some white-line etching
objinfo.watermark: J WHATMAN The watermark appears only in the leaf bearing Object 26 (Bentley Plate 54).
objinfo.pennednumbers: noneFor pencil numbers not by Blake, see Object Order, above.
objinfo.binding: disbound Bound c. 1818 in half green morocco over marbled boards with other works by Blake (see Provenance, below; disbound probably c. 1891. The front fly-leaf of the former binding shows an 1818 watermark (see Bentley page 411).
objinfo.stabholes: originally stabbed through three holes; c.1818 stabbed through seven holes

provenance.name: Houghton Library, Harvard University
provenance.note: Acquired before 1818 by Robert Balmanno; bound by Balmanno with *A Descriptive Catalogue of Pictures* copy I and a copy of *The Prologue and Characters of Chaucer's Pilgrims* (according to Bentley page 411); the New York dealer J. W. Bouton and offered in his *Catalogue of a Magnificent Private Library* of 1868, item 94, bound with *A Descriptive Catalogue of Pictures* copy I, a copy of *The Prologue and Characters of Chaucer's Pilgrims*, and a copy of Blake's broadside, *Little Tom the Sailor* ($100); possibly H. D. Chapin; Edwin William Hooper no later than 1880; his daughter, Mrs. Greely S. Curtis, Jr., by inheritance; her sister, Mrs. Ward Thoron; given 15 Nov. 1950 by Mrs. Thoron to Harvard University.

desc.objtitle: SONGS of Innocence, Object 1 (Bentley 3, Erdman 3, Keynes 3)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a boy with curly hair; the child on the right, with long hair, is probably a girl. To the right of the group is a large apple(?) tree bearing fruit; around the trunk loosely spirals a vine. Various small figures can be seen among the letters of the title, including a piper wearing a broad-brimmed hat standing in the crook of the first letter of "Innocence." Birds fly in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" and above the "N" in "SONGS." Another bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."

component.illusobjdesc: Seen in profile facing right, a nurse or mother in a cap and long dress sits erect in a chair. In her lap she holds a book that two children read.
In her lap a nurse or mother holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the left may be a male with curly hair looking down at the book.

In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read, standing. The child on the right, with long hair and wearing a gown, is probably a girl. Her left arm is bent at the elbow, with the forearm raised horizontally. Her left hand may be pointing to a passage in the book.
In her lap a nurse(?) holds an open book that two children read.
A nurse(?) sits in a chair that faces right.

To the right of the nurse(?) and two children is a large apple(?) tree, bearing fruit (around "of" in the title); around its trunk loosely spirals a vine. The upper leaves on the right of the tree reach near the flame-like vegetative motifs springing from the letters of "SONGS" (leafy extensions of the initial "S," the "N," and the terminal "S" are particularly extravagant).
There may be a tree on the horizon, just right of the trunk of the large tree.
There may be a figure, facing left, sitting on the mid-stroke of the initial "S" in "SONGS." The figure's left(?) leg dangles below the letter.
In the "O" of "SONGS" is a kneeling figure with arms raised in a curve at about 135 degrees.
A tiny form, standing above the left vertical of the "N" in "SONGS," might be a figure walking to the left with arms raised at 45 degrees.
A winged, standing figure leans against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS." The figure may be looking down at and holding a book, reading or writing.
The figure leaning against the middle stroke of the "N" of "SONGS" may be holding a book.
A tiny gowned(?) female(?) figure with at least the left arm raised vertically stands, facing left, in the "G" of "SONGS."
A male piper(?) with a broad-brimmed hat and holding a pipe to his mouth, stands facing left and leaning against the "I" of "Innocence."
A bird flies in the sky beneath and to the left of the "S" in "SONGS."
A bird flies on extended wings above the "N" of "SONGS."
A bird flies upward above the first "n" of "Innocence."
There may be low hills in the landscape.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired nude male (in transparent tights), holding a musical pipe, walks toward the viewer with his left leg forward. This shepherd-piper looks up to the right at a cherubic nude male infant or child floating in a horizontal position on a cloud. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper. The plate is framed by trees on both sides whose leafy branches arch across the top. Behind the piper are grazing sheep and, in the background, more trees. Shadows fall across the ground left of the shepherd.

component.illusobjdesc: Shadows cover a good deal of the ground left of the shepherd's feet.

A curly-haired nude male (in transparent tights), holding a musical pipe, strides toward the viewer with his left leg forward. His left arm is bent at the elbow. The body of this shepherd-piper faces forward but he looks up to the right at a cherubic male child.

A muscular but cherubic nude male infant or child with short hair hovers in a horizontal position on a cloud above the head of a shepherd-piper. The child, with his arms raised horizontally and his legs spread, looks down at the piper.
A cherubic male(?) child hovers on a cloud above the shepherd-piper's head.
A flock of sheep grazes behind the shepherd-piper. Two in the front have their heads down.

Trees frame the plate on both sides. The tree on the left has a single trunk, while the two trees on the right intertwine. Their leafy branches form an arch overhead. There are more leafy trees in the background.
A male shepherd holds a musical pipe.

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels (top left to bottom right): (1) two figures, the front one gowned and seated; (2) a running, leaping, nude(?) figure; (3) a standing figure, perhaps hooded and facing down; (4) an indistinct figure, possibly looking down; (5) at top right, a flying bird with vegetation, perhaps tree limbs and leaves, above and below; (6) a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body; (7) a solitary standing figure, possibly with a flying bird; (8) possibly a seated figure with prominent knees drawn up and vegetation above. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: In the left and right margins leafy vines or branches intertwine to create eight indistinctly drawn panels. The overall structure has sometimes been associated with depictions of the Tree of Jesse. The vines send out tendrils, some of them (top, bottom) loopy, that arch over the top of the plate and fill space between stanzas.

In the panel at top left there are two indistinct figures. The one in the foreground is gowned, seated, possibly hooded, and facing right. The smaller figure to the right may be a standing child or a seated adult, again gowned.
In the second panel down from top left, a nude figure runs or leaps toward us with legs spread and arms raised to 135 degrees.
In the third panel down from top left is a standing figure with head lowered. The figure may be hooded and indulging in some sort of agricultural activity.
There may be a standing figure in the panel lowest on the left, possibly looking down.

In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below. There may be another bird flying above the figure's head in the third panel from the top on this side.
In the panel at top right is a bird flying with vegetation, perhaps the leafy branches of a tree, above and below.
In the second panel from top right is a seated figure facing the viewer with legs crossed and drawn up to the body.
In the third panel from top right is a solitary standing figure, perhaps indulging in some sort of agricultural activity. The figure's left arm may be raised at just under 45 degrees.
There may be a seated figure in the lowest panel on the right, with legs drawn up and knees prominent.
The upper portion of the lowest panel on the right appears to be filled with vegetation of some sort.

lg.l: On a cloud I saw a child.
And he laughing said to me.
Pipe a song about a Lamb;
So I piped with merry chear,
So I piped, he wept to hear.
Drop thy pipe thy happy pipe
Sing thy songs of happy chear,
So I sung the same again
While he wept with joy to hear
Piper sit thee down and write
In a book that all may read__
So he vanish'd from my sight.
And I pluck'd a hollow reed,
And I made a rural pen,
And I stain'd the water clear,
And I wrote my happy songs,
Every child may joy to hear

desc.objtitle: The Ecchoing GreenThe Echoing Green , Object 4 (Bentley 6, Erdman 6, Keynes 6)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A group of four adults—the text mentions "old folk" (Object 4, line 15) and "mothers"(Object 5, line 11)—including two(?) adults on the left, both wearing brimmed hats, and two females wearing a scarf over her head (center) or a cap (right) sit presumably on a circular bench at the base of the trunk of a large oak tree. They superintend five young children who stand at their knees. Behind them five older children play and stroll on a grassy area. The dense, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other trees or bushes fill the background. The shadows along the lower edge of the design suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 16 on the following object).

component.illusobjdesc: On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. In this copy, we clearly see only the left arm, left leg, and hat of the male farthest from us. He may be among the "old folk" (line 15).

On the left end of a bench at the base of the central tree sit two adults. The second adult from the left, hands on his knees, left leg forward, seems to be looking toward the children playing to the left behind the tree. His hat and knee breeches are visible. Long-haired, he may be among the "old folk" (line 15).
A small child with short hair(?) stands at the knees of the first adult sitting on the left side of the tree trunk and looks up at him.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 5, line 11) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. There are two children standing in front of the woman in the center, one at each knee. Her right arm rests on the back of, and perhaps holds, the child at the left. She wears a scarf over her head and faces forward, but with her head twisted to the right.
Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the left, in a gown, lays its head in her lap, face toward the viewer, and may be sleeping.

Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated directly in front of an oak tree. The child on the right, short-haired, nude or clothed in tights(?) and probably male, reaches up with his right hand and rests his left on her knee. He is facing away from the viewer.

Two females in full gowns—nurses or the "mothers" (Object 5, line 11) mentioned in the text—sit on a bench at the base of a large oak tree. There are two children standing at the knees of the woman at the right, and she looks down at them. With her right arm resting in her lap, she holds the left arm of one of the children. She may be wearing a cap.
Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree. The child on the right looks away to the right as the woman holds its arm.

Two children stand at the knees of a woman seated on the right side of the group under the oak tree. Only the head and extended left arm of the child on the left is visible. She or he may be holding onto the woman, who may be holding the child in her lap.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing tights (left) or breeches and a shirt (right) play an unidentified ball game(?). The child at far left, who faces away from the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his right arm at his side, and holding a bat(?) with his raised left hand. A ball is pictured between his head and the bat.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. Left of the tree trunk two male children wearing tights (left) or breeches and a shirt (right) play an unidentified ball game(?). The short-haired child second from left, who faces the viewer, stands with his legs spread, his arms raised horizontally and his palms up or facing the viewer.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children—the nearest one dressed as a male in tights or breeches—walk together, facing left. The front-most youth holds his bent left arm at his side.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. At far right two children walk together, facing left. The features of the child back and furthest right are indistinct.

Behind the adults and young children under the oak tree, five older children play on a grassy area. To the right of the tree trunk stands a short-haired(?) child, arms at his(?) side, who may be playing a ball game with the two standing children to the left of the trunk. He may be wearing breeches and a shirt.

The thick-leaved, umbrella-shaped canopy of the central tree spreads over the entire scene from margin to margin. Other trees or bushes fill the background. The lower reaches of this background vegetation may form a hedge.
The child at the far left holds a bat(?) in his upraised left hand. A ball appears between the bat and his head.
The dark shadows just above the lower margin of the image suggest that the time is late afternoon or early evening ("the darkening Green" of line 16 on the following object).

illustration.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him. The one on the right, also dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand. Leafy grapevines, rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes (over-inked in this impression) to the right of the second stanza. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath. A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the left, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and breeches, stands erect in contrapposto, holding a bat by his side with his right hand while his left hand is hidden behind him.
Two boys flank the first stanza. The one on the right, short-haired, dressed in a shirt and knee breeches, runs behind a large hoop that he rolls with a stick in his right hand.

Leafy grapevines, rooted at the bottom of the plate, flourish to the left and right of the text, and the space between the stanzas is filled with a loopy tendril from the vine on the right, which also bears a cluster of grapes (over-inked in this copy) to the right of the second stanza. The title of the poem is decorated with lively vegetation. A vine sprouts from the initial "T" in the title and the final "n" sends out buds and blossoms that surround the head of the boy beneath.
The boy on the left holds a bat by his side.
A bird with outspread wings and forked tail flies to the right of the grapes.

lg.l: While our sports shall be seen

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text, a procession of nine adults and children (including one infant) in a variety of positions moves generally leftward. Overhead in the branches of two intertwining grape vines that are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin and left to embrace the stanzas of the poem, one boy, left, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes on the left while a second boy, right, hands another cluster to a girl who reaches up from the grass below. Next to her, walking left, is a long-haired male in hat and tights; he holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. Next in line is a woman who looks down at the infant in her arms. A small child stands next to the left. In the center, the tallest figure in the group, perhaps "Old John with white hair" (line 11, Object 5), points forward with his right hand. A boy to the left, who faces away from the viewer, holds a bat at his side with his left hand. At the front of the procession are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that the girl may be holding. The many ink droplets in this copy, clustered around the vines right and left of the text, are probably accidents of inking and thus non-representational.

component.illusobjdesc: Standing on a branch of a luxuriant grapevine, a short-haired boy with his head bent back, seen in profile, stretches on tiptoe to reach a cluster of grapes with his upraised right arm. He may be either nude or wearing tights.

Lying on a branch of a luxuriant grape vine, a curly-haired boy in tights or breeches (note the line just below his right knee) holds a cluster of grapes and hands it down to a girl on the grass below. His right leg is bent at the knee. His body faces forward, with his head turning to the left.

A girl in a full gown and a hat that resembles a halo reaches up with her left hand to take a cluster of grapes from a boy lying on the grapevine above her. At least her left foot is on tiptoe. She looks up toward the grapes.

Walking left among the lower group of figures, second from right, is a long-haired youthful male in brimmed hat and tights or breeches. He holds a bunch of grapes in his extended left hand. His left foot is forward.
Among the lower group of figures, third from the right, stands (or walks) a woman in a full gown who looks down at the infant in her arms. She faces left. Her hair seems to be pulled back in a bun.

Among the lower group of figures, fourth from the right and crowded between two larger adults, stands or walks a small boy in tights(?) who faces forward but looks up toward the woman and infant to the right.
There is an infant in the arms of the woman third from the right among the lower group of figures.

In the center of the lower group of figures, the tallest figure, with long hair, brimmed hat, and dressed in coat and breeches—perhaps "Old John with white hair"—points forward with his right hand. His left arm is at his side, but may be reaching down to the boy holding a bat.

Among the lower group of figures, third from the left, facing away from the viewer, stands (in a contrapposto posture) or walks a short-haired boy in tights (or breeches and shirt) who holds a bat in his extended left hand.

At the front of the procession of figures are a boy, with curly hair and wearing breeches and a shirt, and a girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. His arms are at his side; his head and shoulders are silhouetted against the kite behind him.
At the front of the procession of figures are a boy and girl, both looking back toward the rest of the group. Between them is a kite that she may be holding. She is long-haired and wears a gown.

A luxuriant grapevine, or rather two vines intertwined, are rooted at lower right and grow upward along the right margin. One vine continues up the right margin, while the other branches left to embrace the stanzas of the poem. There are leaves here and there on the vines, a grape cluster at the upper left, over the head of a boy who stretches to pick them, a second cluster beside the head of the boy in the branches on the right, and a third in his hand. There is also a bunch of grapes in the extended left hand of the boy walking to the left, second figure from the right.
There are two children's toys in the lower procession of figures: a kite between the boy and girl on the left, and a bat held by the boy to the right of them.

lg.l: And our sports have an end:
Round the laps of their mothers.

desc.objtitle: The Little Black Boy , Object 6 (Bentley 9, Erdman 9, Keynes 9)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At dawn, an adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child who points upward with his left hand. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably they correspond to the "mother" (lines 2, 6) and "Little Black Boy" (title) of the text. They are both dark of skin. The pair sits under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine twines around the tree (note the semi-circle left of the woman's back and the loop between the tree and the left margin). A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller, grows up the right margin and arches over the sun. A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon. "The rising sun" of the text (line 10) mounts above the horizon in a cloudless sky.

component.illusobjdesc: Under a tree, a dark-skinned adult female, nude above the waist, with a skirt or other drapery on her lap, sits facing a kneeling(?) child. With her right hand she reaches across her lap toward the boy. Presumably she corresponds to the "mother" (lines 2, 6) of the text.

Under a tree, an adult female sits facing a kneeling(?) child, apparently nude and male with short hair, who points upward with his left hand. Presumably he is the "Little Black Boy" of the text. They are both dark of skin.

The mother and child sit under the canopy of a leafy tree whose trunk grows up the left margin behind the mother. A vine twines around the trunk—note the semi-circle left of the woman's back and the loop between the tree and the left margin higher up.
"The rising sun" of the text (line 10) mounts above the horizon in a cloudless but mustard-yellow sky.
A second tree, with fewer leaves and much smaller than the one on the left, grows up the right margin and arches over the rising sun.
A hilly plain stretches to the treeless horizon.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above the lower margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below line 12 of the text. Another vine with loops and leaves fills the right margin above. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black." A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 6, after "tree."

component.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the bottom left, a pair of intertwined vines grows up the left margin and around the words of the title. From the same point at lower left, a third vine, thin with many loops, crosses beneath the last stanza on the plate just above its bottom margin, then continues up the right margin, filling up spaces left by the text and terminating just below the end of line 12. One extension of this vine descends in a spiral in the plate's lower right corner. Above, another vine with loops and leaves fills the remaining spaces right of the text. The capital letters of the title are ornamented to harmonize with the vines, and there is an elaborate bit of detached vegetation between and above "Little" and "Black."
A single bird with outspread wings flies in the margin to the right of line 6, after "tree."

lg.l: My mother bore me in the southern wild,
And I am black, but O! my soul is white.
White as an angel is the English child:
But I am black as if bereav'd of light.
My mother taught me underneath a tree
And sitting down before the heat of day.
She took me on her lap and kissed me,
And pointing to the east began to say.
Look on the rising sun! there God does live
And gives his light. and gives his heat away.
And flowers and trees and beasts and men recieve
Comfort in morning. joy in the noon day.
And we are put on earth a little space.
That we may learn to bear the beams of love,
And these black bodies and this sun-burnt face
Is but a cloud, and like a shady grove.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The elements of the design combine and develop a selection of those on the previous object. Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank. Two nude boys stand in front of him. One, probably the "little English boy" (line 6) whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem, stands at Jesus's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Jesus, who looks down at him. The other boy, probably the little black boy from the previous object though not dark-skinned as he was there (presumably in conformation with the sense of "When I from black and he from white cloud free," line 7), stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 11). All three are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads. A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy. There may be a river running at the foot of the plate. A vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. Another, much shorter vine grows near the left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Christ, in conventional representation as a shepherd with long hair, beard, gown, and crook, sits facing left on a bank with two children standing in front of him. Holding his crook between his legs and across his left shoulder, he rests his left arm on his lap with his hand on his knee. His left foot is exposed.

To the left of the English boy and Christ, a second nude child with short, curly hair, probably the little black boy from the previous object though now not dark-skinned (presumably in conformation with the sense of "When I from black and he from white cloud free," line 7), stands behind the little English boy with his right hand out toward him to "stroke his silver hair" (line 11).

The nude and curly-haired "little English boy" whom the little black boy addresses in the final two stanzas of the poem stands at Christ's knee, holds his hands in a praying gesture, and looks up at Christ, who looks down at him. The boy's right leg is extended backward.
A flock of sheep grazes to the left of the left-most boy.
A few low hills fill the horizon above the sheep.
All three of the figures are sheltered under a leafy, willow-like tree that forms a tight arch over their heads.
A double vine (the smaller, on the left, very short in this copy) rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin. Both stems bear leaves or flowers.
A vine, with leaves and perhaps flowers, grows near the left margin.
Jesus sits on a bank in which a tree and double vine are rooted.
There may be a river running across the foot of the plate.
In a sitting position, Christ holds a shepherd's crook between his legs and across his left shoulder.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

component.illusobjdesc: A flowering(?) vine rooted in the bank to the right of the tree grows up the right margin, and similar but detached vegetation completes the circuit around the top and down the left side of the text. The vine in the left margin is intertwined with another vine.

lg.l: For when our souls have learn'd the heat to bear
The cloud will vanish we shall hear his voice.
Saying: come out from the grove my love & care,
And round my golden tent like lambs rejoice.
Thus did my mother say and kissed me.
And thus I say to little English boy.
When I from black and he from white cloud free,
And round the tent of God like lambs we joy:
Ill shade him from the heat till he can bear,
To lean in joy upon our fathers knee.
And then I'll stand and stroke his silver hair,
And be like him and he will then love me.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides. In its upper reaches there is a circle of eight figures (clockwise from the far right): (1) a nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically; (2) a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sitting on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title; (3) she seems to be holding an infant in her arms; (4) to her left, a nude winged figure, kneeling or sitting, facing left and probably reading a book or tablet below the figure's left hand; (5 and 6) far left, two winged figures who fly facing one another (one facing away from, and the other facing toward, the viewer); (7 and 8) and a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). All the figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central lower pair (2 and 3 above) may be the female blossom who addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

component.illusobjdesc: In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: at far right is a forward-facing nude infant or child flying or running with its arms raised vertically, its left foot forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged figure, probably female, in a gown, sits on part of the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" in the title. She may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, this pair may be the female blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures: in the center, a winged female(?) sitting on the plant just above the "som" of "Blossom" may be holding an infant in her arms. The figures probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text. In that case the infant(?) may represent one of those birds.

The human figures in the plant probably represent, in some fashion, the birds and blossoms that are the subjects of the poem; if so, the central winged female may be the blossom who, as a mother-figure(?), addresses the sparrow and robin in the text.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. Above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title is a winged figure, nude(?), kneeling or sitting, facing left and perhaps reading in the book or tablet to which the figure points with his left arm (raised at about 45 degrees) and hand.
The small winged figure above the "B" of "Blossom" in the title points towards a book or tablet immediately to the left of this figure.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces away from the viewer is perhaps male(?). His arms are raised horizontally, and his legs are spread.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At far left are two nude winged figures who fly facing one another. The one who faces forward is probably another nude putto, but might be female. Its arms are raised at 45 degrees, both to the right, and its legs are together, left forward.

In the upper reaches of a flame-like plant is a circle of eight figures. At top center is a second pair of winged nude figures, kneeling and facing one another, embracing and kissing(?). One leg of the figure on the left is extended backward.
Originating at lower right, an extravagant plant formed of giant, flame-like leaves surrounds the poem on three sides.

desc.objtitle: Nurse's SongNurses Song , Object 9 (Bentley 24, Erdman 24, Keynes 24)

illustration.illusobjdesc: At the bottom, under the lower limb of a tree with a few leaves, seven children—four boys and two, probably three, girls—hold hands and play, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. The two children furthest left stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth, between them. A matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title, sits on the ground against the trunk and reads a book in her lap. To the right is a second, slimmer tree with a vine around its trunk. There are two "hills" (line 13) in the background with a notch between them.

component.illusobjdesc: Seven children hold hands and play vigorously, or perhaps dance, in an incomplete circle. Clockwise from the left: the two children furthest left (a girl[?] and a boy) stretch something, perhaps a piece of cloth used in a game, between them; a girl raises her arms horizontally and faces right with legs outspread; a boy raises his arms higher, as does the long-haired girl to the right of him, whose leg is extended behind her; holding her hand, a boy runs left and reaches forward to hold the hand of another running or striding boy, left leg extended behind him, who raises his free left hand as he moves left and back, perhaps toward the opening between the pair furthest left. All the girls wear gowns; all the boys apparently wear tight-fitting garments. These are the "little ones" who "leaped & shouted & laugh'd" (line 16) and remonstrate with the nurse in the poem.

Facing right, a matron-figure in cap and gown, evidently the nurse of the title who remonstrates with the children of the poem, sits on the ground or a low seat against the trunk of a tree and reads a book that she holds in her lap.

On the left is the trunk of a tree whose lowermost branch, with a few leaves, spreads over the nurse who sits at the base of its trunk. On the right is a second, slimmer tree with a few leaves on its branches and a vine climbing up its trunk. Between the trees is the "green" of line 2.
There are two "hills" (line 13) in the background with a notch between them. Shadows extend below the feet of the children.
The nurse reads a book that she holds in her lap.

illustration.illusobjdesc: On this plate the interlinear designs are especially dense around the title, in the margins, and between the three stanzas. The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are also three prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 5. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 5, 9, and 13) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vinelike structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin. Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," climbing the left stroke and sitting on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one reaching downward through the following "u," joining hands with another who reaches up from below; one leaning against the "S" of "Song" with head propped on one hand, elbow on knee; one at the top of the "S" of "Song," facing right and reaching overhead to grasp the curling vine above; two beneath "Song" on the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one reclining, with right arm raised horizontally, on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 3 and another(?) in a contracted posture on the leafy structure at the end of line 5. Between the lines there are a few birdlike shapes.

component.illusobjdesc: Several human figures populate the network of interlinear vegetation. Clockwise from top left: two on the "N" of "Nurse's," one (nude?) climbing the left stroke and the other sitting, facing right, on a leaf at the end of the curling right stroke; one hovering in the following "u," reaching downward and joining hands with another who reaches up from below, where he/she is seated, facing left, on the end of the long horizontal descender of the "g"; one facing left and leaning, with one leg drawn up, against the "S" of "Song"; one standing(?) at the top of the "S" in "Song," facing right and reaching overhead to grasp the curling vine above; further up on that same descender, two reclining, the one on the left straddling the vegetation; one, right arm raised horizontally and the left drawn back for support, reclining on the bit of vegetation at the end of line 3 and another(?), seated in a contracted posture, on the leafy structure at the end of line 5.
There are two or three birdlike shapes above "for it is" in line 10 and another above "hills" in the last line (line 17).

The title area is full of vegetative swirls, curls, and loops, much of it associated with the extravagant extensions of three letters, the initial capitals "N" and "S" and the terminal "g." There are several long, slender leaves (the descender on the "g," for instance), and there are three other prominent leafy formations in this area: one at the top of the "S," another growing from the "N" of "Nurse's," and the third in the top left corner. Some of the loopy, vine-like decoration dangles in the left margin, and a large leafy structure occupies the space at the end of short line 5. Below it is a leafy weeping willow tree that leans right; its branches arch down into what may be water. Between stanzas (after lines 5, 9, and 13) and, in the right margin, at the ends of short lines are other vine-like structures. The initial letters of stanzas 2, 3, and 4 have extensions that add to the decoration in the left margin.
A few lines may represent water into which the branches of the willow descend.

lg.l: When the voices of children are heard on the green
And laughing is heard on the hill,
My heart is at rest within my breast
And every thing else is still
Then come home my children, the sun is gone down
And the dews of night arise
Come come leave off play, and let us away
Till the morning appears in the skies
No no let us play, for it is yet day
And we cannot go to sleep
Besides in the sky, the little birds fly
And the hills are all coverd with sheep
Well well go & play till the light fades away
And then go home to bed
The little ones leaped & shouted & laugh'd

illustration.illusobjdesc: Eight figures gather around a table that sits on grass against a wall of green vegetation. Five figures sit behind the table, away from the viewer; the female at far right extends her arm to hold a drinking glass that rests on the table. Near the ends of the table on the front side, two other figures sit in chairs that are turned sideways, facing one another. Each figure holds a glass on the table. Between them an eighth figure, a male in tights, stands facing away from the viewer. In upraised hands he holds a glass (right) and a plumed hat (left). The faces of all but one of the figures on the far side of the table are visible. The three figures on the near side face away from the viewer toward the rest of the company. The text mentions "green woods," "meadows," and a "table" in "the shade" (lines 2, 6, 10-11). The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the shadows on the ground.

component.illusobjdesc: At the center is a curly-haired male, possibly nude but probably wearing tights (note the line, perhaps a cuff, on his right wrist). He stands poised and erect facing away from the viewer. His legs are spread; his right leg is straight, his left is extended left, the foot held with its toes pointed. His arms are bent and raised vertically. In his right hand is a wine glass or cup, in his left a hat with a plume. In the context of the poem his actions suggest that he may be singing.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far left is a female with long hair, extending like a braid to the left, and wearing a long gown. Her left leg is extended slightly forward; her right leg is drawn back under her. Her right arm is extended to hold a glass that rests on the table. Her left arm rests on the back of her chair, and her body is twisted counterclockwise as if to face the female across the table from her.

In front of the table and symmetrically placed near its opposite ends are two seated figures, both in chairs turned parallel with the table and toward the center. The figure at far right is a short-haired male, perhaps nude but probably wearing tights. His left leg is extended forward and his foot is visible; his right leg is drawn back under him. His right arm is extended along the table surface to hold a glass; only the upper part of his left is visible near the back of the chair. His lower body faces left, with his torso facing forward and his head twisted clockwise to face the two females across the table.
Five figures are seated behind the table. The figure at far left seems to be a female in a hat with a round brim.
We see the upper body and curly hair of a figure, third from the left. This figure seems to have her or his upper body twisted away from the viewer.

Five figures are seated behind the table. Third from the left is a female with curly hair and wearing a gown. Her head is turned right and tilted up. Her right arm is raised to 45 degrees, her left bent at the elbow.
Five figures are seated behind the table. Second from the right is a female in a high-waisted gown. Her hair is either short or pulled back and curly. She faces forward.
Five figures are seated behind the table. At far right is a female wearing a hat with a round brim. At the end of an outstretched right arm she holds a glass that rests on the table.

Several figures gather around a table that sits on the ground against a wall of vegetation, probably trees. Though the vegetation is not clearly defined, the text mentions "meadows" and "green woods."
The suggestion of a shady refuge is reinforced by the dark shadows on the ground lower right and extending along the lower margin of the design.

In front of the table, near each end, two figures sit in symmetrically-placed chairs turned parallel with the table. The chair on the left has a back and rear legs integrated into a single convex curve. The back of the chair on the right is not clearly represented in this copy. The front legs of the chair on the right curve forward to balance the curve of the rear legs.
Four figures hold drinking glasses. Three rest on the table; the fourth is in the right hand of the central standing figure.
There is a plumed hat with a round brim in the left hand of the central standing figure. The women at far left and far right sitting behind the table also have on round-brimmed hats.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decoration is marginal rather than strictly interlinear. Numerous birds, especially in the bottom margin, ornament areas around the text. There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom. Curving lines left of the second stanza and below and to the left of the final line hint at vines.

component.illusobjdesc: Several birds of various sizes perch and fly on and among the vegetation. Around the title, to the left a bird with outspread wings ascends vertically; another glides over "Song"; and at the right a third dives. In the right margin, after "shade" (line 10), a tiny bird ascends steeply. The small winged creatures farther to the right may be two more birds or insects. Across the bottom of the plate are seven other birds (left to right): two flying above the vine, with outspread wings and the second with a forked tail, the right one ascending; below the vine a third, descending; a fourth, with forked tail, perching on the vine; to its right, above the vine a fifth bird flying, and below the vine, a sixth ascending and, finally, a seventh perching with wings raised.

There are a few decorative extensions on the letters of the title, notably the "L" and "h" of "Laughing," both with loops, and there are vine-like tendrils in the right margin. There is an elaborate tendril with loops and an occasional leaf at the end of the last two lines and across the bottom Curving lines left of the second stanza and below and to the left of the final line hint at vines.

lg.l: When the green woods laugh. with the voice of joy
And the dimpling stream runs laughing by,
When the air does laugh with our merry wit,
And the green hill laughs with the noise of it.
When the meadows laugh with lively green
And the grasshopper laughs in the merry scene,
When Mary and Susan and Emily,
With their sweet round mouths sing Ha, Ha, He,
When the painted birds laugh in the shade
Where our table with cherries and nuts is spread
Come live & be merry and join with me,
To sing the sweet chorus of Ha, Ha, He.

desc.objtitle: The Chimney Sweeper , Object 11 (Bentley 12, Erdman 12, Keynes 12)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The illustration seems to depict chimney sweeper Tom Dacre's dream of liberation for himself and his fellow sweeps by an angel, who releases them from their "coffins of black" to run "naked" down a "green plain" and "wash in a river" (lines 13-17). At bottom right a gowned adult bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth. Across the rest of the bottom of the plate are ten nude figures standing or running with their arms raised in various positions. Two pairs are embracing. Behind the gowned adult a tree grows up the right margin and becomes visually linked to the interlinear decorations.

component.illusobjdesc: At bottom right a gowned adult, presumably the liberating angel of the text, bends forward, reaching toward a nude figure emerging from the earth.

At bottom right a gowned adult reaches down toward a nude figure emerging from the earth. This small figure—probably a child—reaches up with the left arm to hold the adult's hand; the right arm is bent and braced against the coffin or earth. One leg, just emerging from underground, is bent at the knee. The child looks up to the adult.
The dark patch under the child emerging (with the adult's help) from the earth may be a grave.

A pair of nude figures stands with their arms raised at 135 degrees; they may be holding hands. They are most likely two of the liberated nude boys of Tom Dacre's dream in the text—"leaping laughing they run" (line 16).
Two standing figures embrace. These are presumably two of the naked liberated chimney sweepers of the text.

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the fifth and sixth from the left) who seem to be running with their arms raised. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 16).

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the third and fourth from the left) who appear to face each other and embrace, with legs spread apart. Their arms are raised vertically or at 135 degrees. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text.

At bottom left there is a pair of nude figures (the first and second from the left) who appear to be running with arms raised at 135 degrees. These are presumably some of the liberated chimney sweeps of the text-"leaping laughing they run" (line 16).
A thin, leafy, serpentine tree grows up the right margin, ending to the right of the fifth stanza of the poem.
The ground beneath the group of liberated boys suggest the "plain" of the text (line 16).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms (leaves, vines, etc.) and at least five tiny human figures: a chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot and walking to the right within the "C" of the title, a pair of figures sitting on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title, and a pair of figures sitting on the vine or tree right of lines 14-15. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: In the "C" of "Chimney" in the title is a tiny figure that may be a right-facing chimney sweeper carrying a bag of soot.

A pair of tiny figures sit on the tendril above "Sweeper" in the title (and thus may be child chimney sweeps). The one on the left, which tends to merge with the vegetation in this copy, has one arm raised vertically and the other horizontally. He may be holding the vine to the left. The figure on the right, facing left, has at least one arm extended.

A pair of figures (child chimney sweepers?) face each other in the vine, or branches of a tree, right of lines 13-14. The figure on the left stands or leans against the vegetation at his or her back; his or her companion sits. Both have arms raised.

The text and margins are busy with vegetative forms. The capital letters of the title and the lower-case "y" have extravagant extensions with occasional leaves and perhaps flowers. The extension at the top of the "S" joins the vegetation in the right margin to wrap around the right end of the title and descend as a loopy vine in the right margin. Other bits of vine-like structures—some of them extensions of the marginal vegetation, some of letters in the text—fill the spaces between quatrains of text, while the tree and other vegetation in the right margin fill spaces at the ends of short lines. The vegetation right of lines 14-15, in which two figures are pictured, may be a tree.

lg.l: When my mother died I was very young,
And my father sold me while yet my tongue,
Could scarcely cry weep weep weep weep.
So your chimneys I sweep & in soot I sleep.
Theres little Tom Dacre, who cried when his head.
(That curl'd like a lambs back, was shav'd, so I said.
Hush Tom never mind it, for when your head's bare,
You know that the soot cannot spoil your white hair,
And so he was quiet, & that very night.
As Tom was a sleeping he had such a sight,
That thousands of sweepers Dick, Joe, Ned & Jack
Were all of them lock'd up in coffins of black,
And by came an Angel who had a bright key,
And he open'd the coffins & set them all free,
Then down a green plain leaping laughing they
And wash in a river and shine in the Sun.
Then naked & white, all their bags left behind,
They rise upon clouds, and sport in the wind.
And the Angel told Tom if he'd be a good boy,
He'd have God for his father & never want joy.
And so Tom awoke and we rose in the dark
And got with our bags & our brushes to work.
Tho' the morning was cold, Tom was happy & warm.
So if all do their duty, they need not fear harm.

objnote.p: The plate is in the first state, with the descender of the "J" of "Joy" in the title cutting across and appearing below the upper edge of the flower. This lower extension of the descender was removed prior to printing all other extant impressions. The only other first-state impression is in Songs of Innocence copy W.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding an infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. Each of her small wings is marked with a dot. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 6). A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the center-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one. The dots of ink surrounding the head of the woman holding the infant are probably not representational.

component.illusobjdesc: Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. At left, a long-haired, gowned female sits holding a nude infant. Facing right, she looks down at it as she rests her right arm across it. To the right, facing them, stands a winged and gowned female angel who looks down at the infant and holds her hands out toward it. The infant and seated mother(?) may be identified with the two speakers of the poem; there, the infant names itself "Joy" (line 6).

Rooted at the lower right edge of the plate, a leafy, blooming plant with two major stems embraces the text of the poem above. The lesser stem, which culminates in a drooping closed blossom or unopened bud, grows in an s-curve up the right margin. The greater stem curves left and then up the left margin. It culminates in a large and lavish blossom whose flame-like petals open into the space above the text. Within the blossom, in place of stamens and pistils, are three figures. A third stem of the plant, with no blossom but with large leaves, grows across the bottom of the plate alongside the major stem; in the middle-left margin yet another stem sprouts from the main one.

lg.l: I am but two days old.__
Sweet joy but two days old,

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to toward the nose of one of them—perhaps the "little lamb" of the text—with his hands. Behind the flock are a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left) and a cottage or barn (right) with a doorway or window. On its thatched roof perch two birds, often identified as doves. Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout leaves and several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: In a grassy landscape, a nude boy with short hair stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep. He reaches out toward the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.

A nude boy stands in contrapposto in front of a flock of sheep—some grazing, some standing, some lying down. The boy reaches out to toward the nose of one of them—perhaps the "Little Lamb" of the text—with his hands.
Behind the flock of sheep is a leafy oak tree with a large trunk (left).

Two slender trees, one on each side, frame the plate. Both trees are intertwined with vines that sprout several loopy tendrils. Where the tree branches meet and intertwine at the top, creating an arch between the title and the text of the poem, they are leafy. Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.
On the roof of a cottage or barn perch two birds, often identified as doves.
Behind the flock of sheep is a cottage or barn (right) with a thatched roof and a doorway or window.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

component.illusobjdesc: Vines or branches grow across the plate near its midpoint to help fill the space between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Dost thou know who made thee
Gave thee life & bid thee feed.
By the stream & o'er the mead;
Gave thee such a tender voice,
Dost thou know who made thee
He is called by thy name,
For he calls himself a Lamb:
He is meek & he is mild,
I a child & thou a lamb,
We are called by his name.

desc.objtitle: The Little Boy lost , Object 14 (Bentley 13, Erdman 13, Keynes 13)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 9: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 2, 4). A tree rises on the right and branches over the child's head. The cave-like background may be formed of vegetation.

component.illusobjdesc: In the darkness, a small boy in a gown holds his arms out toward a triangle of light on the left. The dark area above his head might indicate a hat. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1). His hair appears to be curly.
A leafless tree grows on the right. One branch extends toward the top right corner of the design; another extends above the child. The cave-like background may be formed of vegetation.
The boy wanders at night in the darkness. The cave-like background may be formed of vegetation.

A small boy holds his arms out toward a triangle of light at the left. He is presumably the "Little Boy lost" (line 1), who in the text mistakes a "vapour" (line 9: i.e., will o' the wisp) for his "father" (lines 2, 4).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, four winged. The letters of the title sprout vegetative extensions, and there are other bits of vegetation amidst the angels (notably at the bottom), between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There are also two seated figures in the title letters, one facing left on the "L" of "Little" (line 1) and one with raised arm in the "B" of "Boy." There might be a figure, seen from behind, reclining on the lower curve of the "B." There are four flying birds and a swan or duck among the lines of the title and the first stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The text is surrounded on the bottom and sides by six angels, all probably female. They are symmetrically arranged, two beside each stanza and two, aligned foot to foot, beneath. They all seem to be gowned, and the four in the right and left margins have wings. The two in the right margin have their arms at their sides; the two wingless figures below float or fly horizontally with one arm raised (with banners or flags of drapery arranged symmetrically); the lower figure in the left margin has its arms by its side; the upper figure on that side faces right, has its left arm raised vertically, and may be pointing to the scene above.

There are two figures sitting in the title letters, one facing left, with bent arm raised to its head and at least one leg dangling, on the "L" of "Little" (line 1), the other sitting with arm raised at about 135 degrees in the "B" of "Boy." There might be a figure, seen from behind, reclining on the lower curve of the "B."

Four birds fly among the lines of the title and the first stanza: over "lost" in the title (line 1), over "where" and "going" in line 2, and after "fast" in line 3. There is a swan or duck, facing right above the "y" of "Boy."

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above most of the title (line 1). The "y" of "Boy" is extended, and an unattached clump of plant-like decoration surrounds the right end of the title. There are other bits of leafy (and/or flowery) vegetation around the two figures at the bottom, between the quatrains of the poem, and at the ends of shorter lines. There is a particularly loopy, leafy tendril after line 5 and between the two stanzas.

lg.l: Father, father, where are you going
O do not walk so fast.
Speak father. speak to your little boy
Or else I shall be lost,
The night was dark no father was there
The child was wet with dew.
The mire was deep, & the child did weep

desc.objtitle: The Little Boy found , Object 15 (Bentley 14, Erdman 14, Keynes 14)

illustration.illusobjdesc: In a dark landscape dominated by the trunks of three large trees, a long-haired adult figure, visually ambiguous but male according to the text, dressed in a high-waisted long gown holds the arm of a gowned child. The two figures look at one another as they walk forward, on rather barren ground, toward the viewer. A thin halo appears above the adult's head; the child appears to be wearing a hat with a halo-like brim. The child raises his right arm to hold the adult's arm. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 2- 6).

component.illusobjdesc: A long-haired adult figure in a high-waisted long gown—visually ambiguous though the reference to "God . . . like his father" (lines 4-5) suggests that he is male—walks beside a boy whose arm he holds (he holds his opposite arm by his side). The thin rim of a halo appears above his head. If this is God, it is very probably Christ, given the similarities between this figure and several of Blake's other representations of Christ. Both feet are exposed; his left foot is forward. He looks down toward the boy.

The two figures walk forward toward the viewer. A gowned male child with short hair walks forward toward the viewer beside a similarly dressed adult whose arm he holds and up at whom he looks. The child raises his left arm at 45 degrees, his right at 135 degrees; he steps forward with his right leg. The child wears a hat with a halo-like brim. The text describes the "little boy lost" who is "by the hand led" to safety by "God . . . like his father in white" (lines 2-6).

A dark landscape—the "lonely dale" (line 8) of the text—is dominated by three large and ominous tree trunks, two left and one right. There may be a few leaves top right. The trunks and branches arch to create a kind of dark tunnel in which the two figures walk.

The darkness suggests that the time is still the "night" (line 6) specified in "The Little Boy lost" (Object 14). What appear to be the crests of two hills or mountains above the child's head divide the dark landscape from the nighttime sky.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit with long hair flies with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title and into the left margin; another group of detached vegetative decorations fills the space below the poem and up the right margin to the angelic spirit.

component.illusobjdesc: A gowned angelic spirit, probably female, floats with arms outstretched, facing left, in the right margin. She looks sharply upward, as if at the design above. Her gown and a loop of drapery right of her back trail behind her. This may be the child's "mother" (line 7) to whom he is led.

The letters of the title sprout vine-like vegetative extensions that extend above and below most of the title. The capital letters of the title all have such extensions. The "y" of "Boy" (line 1) extends far to the left and down the left margin, and the vertical stroke of the "d" of "Found" is extravagantly extended to fill the space above the angel. Another cluster of vine-like decorations begins in the right margin in front of the legs of the angel and extends downward (with loops and leaves) into the space below the poem.

lg.l: The little boy lost in the lonely fen,
Began to cry, but God ever nigh,
Appeard like his father in white.
He kissed the child & by the hand led
Who in sorrow pale. thro' the lonely dale

illustration.illusobjdesc: A slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 18. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Just left of the trees, lower right, a lion lies in a cave with vegetation arching over it. There are winged angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings (or one wing and an arm) outspread at top right, a second sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first, and a third hovering just above the lion's den. Two birds perch on a branch right of line 5. In the left margin are other figures and objects (bottom to top): one gowned, standing on the shadowed ground and facing the third stanza; just above that, a figure with one arm raised; another, arms raised vertically, standing on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, smaller, with wings and arms outspread. All the figures may be the angels described in the text (Object 16, stanzas 2-3; Object 17, stanza 1). Above the top figure on the left, left of line 5, is another sphere (the sun or moon?); scattered across this same space in the left margin are nine or ten dots, perhaps stars.

component.illusobjdesc: There are winged, gowned angelic figures in the tree, one standing with wings (or a wing and one arm) outspread at top right; a second, facing right, sitting with wings folded on a branch beneath the first; and a third, with arms raised horizontally, hovering or standing on one foot just above the lion's den.

In the left margin are other figures (bottom to top): one gowned, standing and facing right toward the third stanza; just above that, a figure who seems to be facing forward with right arm raised; another standing, arms raised vertically, on a sphere (the sun or moon?); just above that another, with wings and arms outspread.

Rooted at bottom right, a slender tree with leafy branches grows up the right margin, bends under and around the left end of the title—whose lettering harmonizes with the surrounding foliage—and curves back over it. A second tree, much smaller, is also rooted lower right; its branches cross in front of and behind the larger tree above the angel opposite "nest" in line 18. A second branch of the larger tree continues up the right side of the plate to complete the circle around the title. Several leafy branches extend left into the spaces left by short lines of the poem. The tree is loosely encircled by a leafy vine whose termination, perhaps a little beyond the point where the tree bends left, is unclear. Some indeterminate vegetation extends in an arch over the cave, lower right.
In the hill or bank at right is a cave. Alternatively, this formation may be composed of arching vegetation.
Two birds perch on a branch right of line 5.
A lion lies facing forward in a cave.

In the left margin are two small circles, probably representing spheres, one above the figures and the other beneath the feet of the second figure from the top. One may be the moon and the other the sun. Between the two spheres are nine or ten scattered dots that may represent stars.
The style of lettering in the title integrates it into the tree.

lg.l: The sun descending in the west,
The birds are silent in their nest,
And I must seek for mine,
Sits and smiles on the night.
Farewell green fields and happy groves,
Where lambs have nibbled, silent moves
They look in every thoughtless nest,
They visit caves of every beast,
To keep them all from harm;
They pour sleep on their head
And sit down by their bed.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. On the ground, in front of a backdrop of plants, five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To the left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left. In the tree trunk in the left margin are two other gowned female figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. The lowest stands on a limb of the tree and has one arm raised vertically; the top-most may face forward (the position of her head is unclear in this copy).

component.illusobjdesc: Five gowned female(?) figures stand in two groups. To the right, just under the branches, one female faces left and points or gestures left with her upraised left arm as she turns to look at her companion, who faces forward but looks left toward her companion. To their left, close to the tree trunk, stand three other females, perhaps walking. The left-most figure has her arms crossed and looks right. The one in the middle, who seems to have long hair, looks forward; the one to the right looks left. These may be the angels mentioned in the text (stanzas 2-3, Object 16; stanza 1, Object 17).

In the tree trunk in the left margin are two gowned female figures, perhaps the angels mentioned in the text. The lowest figure stands on a limb and raises one arm vertically. The figure above, left of the first stanza on this plate, may be facing forward (her head position is unclear in this copy).

A large tree, with a leafy vine lower left, grows up the left margin, while its long, leafy branches extend above and behind (as it were) the text well into the right margin. Five figures stand on the ground against a backdrop of plants or other vegetation.

lg.l: When wolves and tygers howl for prey
Seeking to drive their thirst away,
And keep them from the sheep.
And there the lions ruddy eyes,
Shall flow with tears of gold:
And now beside thee bleating lamb.
I can lie down and sleep;
Or think on him who bore thy name.
As I guard o'er the fold.

desc.objtitle: The School Boy , Object 18 (Bentley 53, Erdman 53, Keynes 53)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Below the text are three boys playing a game (of marbles?) on the ground. To the right of the boys is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. On the vines are four other children: (bottom to top) one—long-haired and thus perhaps a girl—standing with arms raised, two boys(?) climbing, and another boy(?) sitting and reading. In the left margin are a slender tree and a vine intertwined with it. A large bird perches near the top, left of the first stanza, and a figure stands, perhaps facing right, just left of the fourth stanza.

component.illusobjdesc: The short-haired boy in tights (note the belt or fold at his waist) on the left kneels on the ground with his arm down, as if poised to shoot a marble in the game that he and the other children present are playing.

The short-haired boy, nude or wearing tights, in the middle kneels, leaning forward, with his arms braced to support his weight. He looks down toward the hand of the boy to the left. His left leg is bent under him; his right leg is extended to the left.

The right-most child—apparently male—in the group below the text has short hair and is nude or wears tights. He is sitting, bending sharply forward with head and arms down. Though facing left, he appears to be looking down at the ground rather than at the game.

A long-haired girl or boy, nude or wearing tights, stands at the intersection of two vines, perhaps in the process of climbing them (like the figure just above it). The left-facing figure's head is thrown sharply back, its arms are raised vertically to hold onto the vines above its head, and its weight is on its extended left leg.

A short-haired boy (nude or wearing tights?) climbs in the intertwining vines that extend up the right margin. Facing forward(?), he raises his arms vertically to hold onto the vines over his head. His right leg is drawn up toward his body; his left leg is extended along the vine.

A child (nude or wearing tights?), probably a boy though other identifying features are not shown, climbs the vine. His arms are raised vertically to cling to the vines over his head. His legs are spread wide.
Facing right, a child of indeterminate sex (nude or wearing tights?) sits in a curve at the top of a vine in the right margin. He holds, and appears to be reading, a book.
The figure sitting at the top of the vines on the right appears to be reading an open book.
