A figure stands, probably gowned and facing right, in the tree left of the fourth stanza. The figure's right arm appears to be bent at the elbow.
A bird with long forked tail and wings partially spread perches in the vegetation to the left of the first stanza.

Behind the right-most figure below the text is a bit of indeterminate spiny vegetation—perhaps grass—and two large intertwining grapevines extending up the right margin to the top of the plate. The vines have numerous tendrils and leaves and one large cluster of fruit, to the right of line 20.
Rooted at lower left, a slender tree with leaves extends up the left margin and ends opposite line 7(?). An intertwined vine climbs the tree, with one loop left of the fifth stanza.
Three children play a game, perhaps marbles. Four(?) marbles are just barely visible on the ground beneath the right-most child.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 1) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal trees and vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration). Tendrils from the vines in the right margin—part of the main illustration—are extended into some of the spaces left by short lines.

component.illusobjdesc: Title letters "T," "S," "B," and "y" (line 1) have loopy vine-like extensions that relate them to the marginal vines. The first of these, upper left, descends in loops and supports a bird (considered here to be part of the main illustration).

lg.l: I love to rise in a summer morn,
When the birds sing on every tree;
The distant huntsman winds his horn,
And the sky-lark sings with me.
But to go to school in a summer morn,
O! it drives all joy away;
The little ones spend the day,
Ah! then at times I drooping sit,
And spend many an anxious hour,
Nor in my book can I take delight,
Worn thro' with the dreary shower.
How can the bird that is born for joy,
Sit in a cage and sing.
How can a child when fears annoy.
O! father & mother, if buds are nip'd,
And if the tender plants are strip'd
Of their joy in the springing day,
How shall the summer arise in joy,
Or how shall we gather what griefs des
When the blasts of winter appear.

desc.objtitle: On Anothers SorrowOn Another's Sorrow , Object 19 (Bentley 27, Erdman 27, Keynes 27)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right edge of the plate. A vine grows up around its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7. At the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near the bird with long tail feathers that ascends to the right of stanza 6. Other birds fly to the right of lines 3, 6, and 12. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. The left margin is dominated by a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree. A figure playing a pipe stands next to the right tree, lower left. There is a second figure climbing in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. There may also be a third figure with arms raised, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, although the figure merges with the tendrils in this copy. A fourth human form, left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised.

component.illusobjdesc: There may be as many as four figures in the left margin, although only three are clearly pictured in this copy. A figure, facing left, stands at the base of the tree on the left and plays a pipe. A second figure climbs in the branches above, opposite stanza 7. A third, opposite stanzas 2 and 3, raises his arms as if in supplication—although in this copy the figure is hard to separate from the vines. The final figure, clearly represented left of stanza 1, stands facing right with at least one arm raised vertically.
A bird with long tail feathers ascends to the right of stanza 6. Three other birds fly to the right of lines 3, 6, and 12.

A lithe and leafy tree, rooted bottom right, grows up the right margin. A vine grows up its trunk; grape clusters are visible opposite stanzas 6 and 7; at the midway point the vine seems to produce the loopy tendril that terminates near stanza 6. The letters of the title are ornamented with elaborate extensions and flourishes. The three capital letters, along with the "h" of "Anothers," which is decorated with a kind of forked top above and a long flag below, and the coil following the final "w," are the most notable. In the left margin is a lattice of branches from two thin trees rooted at bottom left. Leafless below, the branches in the upper reaches of the margin carry the suggestion of leaves, and there are very loopy tendrils beside the first three stanzas that may be a separate vine or part of the tree.
The standing figure at bottom left is playing a pipe.

lg.l: And not be in sorrow too.
And not seek for kind relief.
Can I see a falling tear.
And not feel my sorrows share,
Can a father see his child,
Weep, nor be with sorrow fill'd.
Can a mother sit and hear.
An infant groan an infant fear__
No no never can it be.
And can he who smiles on all
Hear the wren with sorrows small.
Hear the small birds grief & care
Hear the woes that infants bear__
And not sit beside the nest
And not sit the cradle near
And not sit both night & day.
O! no never can it be.
He doth give his joy to all,
He becomes a man of woe
He doth feel the sorrow too.
Think not, thou canst sigh a sigh,
And thy maker is not by.
Think not. thou canst weep a tear,
And thy maker is not near.
O! he gives to us his joy,
That our grief he may destroy
Till our grief is fled & gone
He doth sit by us and moan

desc.objtitle: A CRADLE SONG , Object 20 (Bentley 16, Erdman 16, Keynes 16)

illustration.illusobjdesc: Indeterminate (but varied) vegetation interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. There are three figures in the letters "A," "C," and "D" of the title (line 1); five in the left margin; and five(?) in the right.

component.illusobjdesc: There are three figures in the letters of the title (line 1): a piper, facing left, playing(?) as he leans against the left side of the "A"; a figure, facing right, sitting inside the "C"; and a figure standing, probably facing forward, inside the "D."
A piper plays his pipe(?) as he leans against the letter "A" in the title (line 1).

There are five figures in the left margin (top to bottom): a gowned woman(?) standing with her arm raised vertically beside the second stanza; a small winged(?) figure next to "Hover" (line 11), and just beneath it a sitting, hunched over figure; a seated, gowned, hunched over figure with head lowered, left of the fifth stanza; and, beside the sixth stanza, a standing figure with head up and arm raised.

There are five(?) figures visible in the right margin (top to bottom): a gowned figure seated, with head down, right of line 4; a gowned female(?) figure lying horizontally, arm extended, in the flame-like vegetation to the right of lines 5 and 6; possibly a figure standing in the vines right of lines 10-11, legs spread and arms raised to hold the vegetation above; a figure seated facing left on a vine right of lines 15-16 with one arm behind its back and braced against the vine, the other arm extended with the hand on the knee; and a figure walking right at the end of lines 16-17.

Indeterminate vegetation of various sorts interspersed with tiny human figures surrounds the text, especially left, right, and top, and fills spaces between all the stanzas. The dominant form is perhaps the vegetation with flame-like leaves that swirls in the spaces of the right margin (with a more conventional leaf or two at bottom right), underneath the title, and down the left margin. Tendrils extending from both margins help separate the stanzas from one another. The vine right of the final stanza on the plate has several loops suggesting a spiral. The vine full of leaves and flowers(?) that extends across the top of the plate above the title and fills the top right corner and the space right of the first stanza is distinct from the flame-like vegetation that dominates the rest of the plate. Extensions of letters in the title (line 1) contribute to both forms of vegetation: the initial "A" and "C" to the vine above, the "S" to both. In the text of the poem, occasional letters have modest decorative extensions, and there are a few bits of stray decorative vegetation.

lg.l: Weave thy brows an infant crown.
Chase not slumber from thy eyes,
While o'er thee thy mother weep
Thy maker lay and wept for me

illustration.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat or headdress of some sort leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a hooded wicker cradle. The infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 7). A carpet with a complex pattern covers the floor. Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.

component.illusobjdesc: From a sitting position in a curved-back chair, a female nurse or mother, dressed in a high-waisted gown and hat, scarf, or headdress of some sort, leans over an infant in a cradle. She faces right; at least her right arm, and probably her left, are folded in front of her.

A nurse or mother leans over a swaddled infant who sleeps in a cradle. The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo, and the speaker of the poem proposes an identification of the smiling infant with Christ: "Infant smiles are his own smiles" (line 7).
The configuration of the infant's pillow suggests a halo.
An infant sleeps in a wicker cradle with handles and a hood that arches over the infant's head.
A carpet with an elaborate pattern covers the floor.
Fabric hung between vertical uprights creates a curtain-like screen in the background.
The mother or nurse sits in a curved-back chair.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 5) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the left margin and beneath the text. In the left margin there are four human figures: beside the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands with an infant(?) in her arms; left of lines 5-6 is a running or leaping figure facing right with its legs spread and its arms raised horizontally; and left of line 7 is a small gowned figure facing, and perhaps walking, left, also with its legs spread.

component.illusobjdesc: The two dominant kinds of vegetation from the previous object reappear here: a vine-like tendril over the text that ends in a flourish of flame-like leaves in the top right corner; and a second tendril that separates the two stanzas and expands into an extravagant cluster with shorter leaves and a large loop (after a small loop above "on" in line 5) in the right margin beside the second stanza. There are other bits of vegetation in the right margin and beneath the text. Two of these are extensions of letters in the text: the "S" of "Smiles" (line 5) and the "p" of "peace" (line 8).
Left of the first stanza, a gowned woman(?) stands, facing right, with an infant(?) in her arms.
Left of lines 5-6, a small figure strides or leaps or hovers in the air, facing right. Its legs are spread apart and its arms raised horizontally.
A tiny figure, perhaps gowned, hovers or walks to the left just left of line 7. Its legs are spread apart. This may be the "infant" referenced in the first word of line 7.

lg.l: Wept for me for thee for all.
When he was an infant small.
Heavenly face that smiles on thee.
Smiles on thee on me on all,
Infant smiles are his own smiles,

desc.objtitle: The Divine Image. , Object 22 (Bentley 18, Erdman 18, Keynes 18)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at right in the strip of grassy ground that runs across the bottom of the plate, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward flourish at top left. The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin right of the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant, which the vine continues to climb, finally terminating just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure. There are several human figures on and around the plants: (at top left) a gowned female with long hair walks right; a second gowned female with long hair floats behind her, pointing right; two figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer; (at bottom right) a gowned figure stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically; below and in front of this pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm.

component.illusobjdesc: At top left, a gowned woman with long hair walks right; her right arm is drawn back behind her. Her left arm is at her side and she may be holding an object in her left hand. Another gowned female with long hair hovers behind her, pointing right.
Two gowned figures kneel side by side, facing right, hands raised in prayer.

At bottom right, a figure in a high-waisted gown stands, with an arm extended, perhaps touching the left hand of a short-haired nude male figure to the left, who reclines with his right arm braced for support, his left raised vertically toward the hand of the standing figure. Below and in front of the male pair, a third figure, perhaps a nude female, reclines, supported on her left arm. Her body faces forward, and her head appears to be turned slightly to the right and down. The male and female conceivably represent Adam and Eve; the standing gowned figure may be Christ.

A serpentine plant-like structure with flame-like leaves, apparently rooted at bottom right, grows along the ground under the last stanza and then up the left margin. Between stanzas three and four the plant forks. One part continues up the left margin and ends under the title. Another part of the plant curves between the third and fourth stanzas and crosses into the right margin, curves back over the title and ends in an upward curl at top left.

The large plant is encircled in its upper reaches by a leafy vine that is rooted, like the plant itself, at the bottom right corner. From there the vine climbs up the right margin behind the standing figure and then, after arching over the figure's head, onto the flame-like plant (sending out occasional tendrils to the left, into the spaces left by short lines of the poem) until it terminates in a cluster of leaves that dangles just left of the title. A second vine, much shorter, appears in front of the plant at the bottom of the plate, left of the reclining figure.

lg.l: To Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
And to these virtues of delight.
For Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
And Mercy Pity Peace and Love,
Is Man his child and care.
For Mercy has a human heart
And Love, the human form divine.
Then every man of every clime,
Prays to the human form divine
And all must love the human form,

illustration.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. A few of the boys may wear hats. They are led by a pair of gowned adults, both with hats, one carrying a staff or scepter. At the bottom of the plate a similar procession occurs, though with seven pairs of girls instead of nine of boys, walking left instead of right, and led by a single gowned female(?) figure who may be holding something (more clearly a book in other copies). The girls wear dresses, possibly with aprons. The figures altogether represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 2-6).

component.illusobjdesc: Nine pairs of uniformed boys in coats walk to the right across the top of the plate. The precise positions of the children are not always clear. Some of the boys may be holding one another. Several of the boys may wear hats or caps. Along with the figures at the bottom, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" (lines 3-5).

The procession of children is led by a pair of robed adults, probably male(?), both with hats, one holding a staff or scepter. They are the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" (line 5).
A beadle at the head of the procession holds a staff or scepter, one of the "wands" (line 5) of the text.

Seven pairs of girls walk left, led by a single adult figure. The girls wear uniform dresses, perhaps with aprons. They may be wearing hats or head coverings of some sort. Their positions are not always clear; girls in the fourth and fifth pairs from the right gesture with their hands. Along with the figures at the top, these represent the charity children of the text, "walking two & two" behind the "Grey headed beadles" who "walkd before with wands" into St. Paul's cathedral "on a Holy Thursday" (lines 2-6).
The procession of girls is led by a single gowned figure, of indeterminate gender, who may be holding something (more clearly a book in other copies). The figure appears to be wearing a wig or cap.
The robed figure who is leading the procession may be wearing a cap or wig and possibly holding something (more clearly a book in other copies).

illustration.illusobjdesc: The text is crowded with a mixture of interlinear vegetation, animals, birds, and human figures. The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 1]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird (below "into the" in line 6) or human figure (beneath "innocent" in line 10). Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves but including a bird perching on a vine, wings outspread, facing the viewer. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

component.illusobjdesc: There is a tiny human figure, running or hovering with arms raised horizontally, beneath "innocent" in line 10. Some of the decorations are suggestive of human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

There are birds beneath "into the" in line 6—flying to the right—and beneath "you drive" in line 14—perching and facing forward, with wings outspread, on a vine. The latter bird may be an eagle. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) but are more likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

The block letters of the title are surrounded by vine-like loops and flame-like leaves (attached to the "H" and "L" of "HOLY" and the "S" and "Y" of "THURSDAY" [line 1]) and combinations of those with other long-leaved plants (especially under the title). Many of the letters of the long-lined poem have decorative vine-like extensions. After the area around the title, the most extravagant decoration is reserved for the spaces between stanzas, where rows of leaves and vines (most of them originating in extensions of letters of the text in lines adjacent to the spaces) alternate with an occasional bird or human figure. Beneath the final stanza is another particularly busy area of decoration, dominated by vines and leaves. Some of the decorations are suggestive of birds (e.g., above "Seated" in line 8 and above "their" in line 10) or human figures (e.g., on the sprig of vegetation beneath the "Y" of "HOLY") but are equally likely to be bits of vine or leaf.

lg.l: Twas on a Holy Thursday their innocent faces clean
The children walking two & two in red & blue & green
Grey headed beadles walkd before with wands as white as
Till into the high dome of Pauls they like Thames waters flow
O what a multitude they seemd these flowers of London town
Seated in companies they sit, with radiance all their own
The hum of multitudes was there but multitudes of lambs
Thousands of little boys & girls raising their innocent hands
Now like a mighty wind they raise to heaven the voice of song
Or like harmonious thunderings the seats of heaven among
Beneath them sit the aged men wise guardians of the poor
Then cherish pity, lest you drive an angel from your door

illustration.illusobjdesc: Sitting beneath the branches of a tree with its trunk behind her, a gowned woman with hair pulled back looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. Low hills define the horizon above the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.

component.illusobjdesc: Sitting to the right of a large tree trunk, a gowned woman with hair pulled back into a bun looks out toward a flock of grazing sheep. She holds a nude infant—perhaps her own—who stands in her lap. Her right foot is visible beneath the hem of her gown.

A seated woman holds her(?) short-haired nude infant, who stands in her lap and gestures with upraised arms toward the sheep. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem.
A mother and her(?) infant overlook a flock of grazing sheep. In the final stanza of the poem, an infant or child speaks to a "Little Lamb," and this may be the animal with head raised.
The horizon above the sheep is defined by low hills.
The leaves of a tree, its trunk just right of the left margin, extend over the woman and infant.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and two tassels of grain. Another vine, also with two grain tassels, curves around the end of long line 10 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate. Two winged angels occupy this vegetation, one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe right of lines 2-3; the other reclining on one arm right of line 11.

component.illusobjdesc: Two winged angels with obscure features occupy the vegetation to the right of the text: one seated, facing right, and playing a pipe opposite lines 2-3; the other, wings outspread, reclining on one arm opposite line 11.

Most of the decorative vegetation seems to originate in and around the title lettering. A vine curls left of the "S" of "Spring" and dangles (with loops and leaves) down the left margin of the text. Another cluster of vegetation bursts from the side of the "g" of "Spring"; curls back over the title; expands downward into the large spaces of the right margin with long, thin leaves, a loopy tendril, and two tassels of grain. Another vine, also with two grain tassels, curves around the end of long line 10 and expands into the space left by the remaining short lines on the plate.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with curly hair reclines on grassy(?) ground. With both hands the infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Two sheep also lie on the ground, left and right of the infant. He may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 8).

component.illusobjdesc: A nude infant with short, curly hair reclines, with his left leg crossed over his extended right leg, in the midst of a group of three sheep. With his left hand he touches the neck—and with his right the back—of a lamb to the left; the two of them look at one another. The infant may be the one who speaks to the "Little Lamb" in the final stanza of the poem (line 8).

An infant touches a lamb to the left, and the two of them look at one another. Grown sheep lie on the left and right; the one on the right faces forward while the one on the left appears to be watching the lamb and infant.
The reticulated surface of the ground below the lamb and child may indicate grass.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two grain tassels grow from this framing vine; the lower tassel dangles just right of the vignette. Two clusters of similar vegetation, each with one or more grain tassels, fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There is a figure associated with each cluster of vegetation in the right margin: below, a gowned angel with large wings sitting on a curve of the plant with her(?) knees drawn up and her head down; above, a gowned figure standing, with arms outspread, in a semi-circle made by the plant.

component.illusobjdesc: Right of the first stanza, a gowned figure stands in a semi-circle made by a vine or leaf. Her(?) arms are outspread, partially hidden by the vine-like plant that circles around in front of her. Her body may be twisting away from the viewer.
Right of the last stanza, a winged, gowned angel sits on a curve of the plant with her(?) legs drawn up and her head down, her body facing left.

Vine-like extensions of the "L's" in the initial words of the two stanzas on this plate dangle, with loops and leaves, in the left margin, and the lower extension divides into tendrils that wrap almost completely around the vignette at bottom. Two clusters of similar vegetation fill the spaces left in the right margin by the short lines of the poem. There are grain tassels at the right side of the lower vignette, to the right of lines 13-15, below the last two words in line 7, and just below the top right corner of the plate.

desc.objtitle: The Voice of the Ancient Bard. , Object 26 (Bentley 54, Erdman 54, Keynes 54)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A gowned, bearded old man stands, playing a large harp, before an audience of perhaps two children—standing in the middle of the group—and six older youths. He may be the bard of the title. To the left stand two young females who embrace. To the right stand the two children and a group of three gowned females who face the bard. At their feet, facing them, kneels another female. All the figures appear to be gowned. The scene is set outdoors on a strip of slightly inclined ground with a dark shadow lower right. A palm-like frond arches over the head of the figure at far right and the vine in the left margin of the text dangles down into this major design above the heads of the embracing couple.

component.illusobjdesc: At left stands an embracing couple. A young female faces away from the viewer with her visible arm raised vertically to hold the shoulder of her companion. Both would appear to be gowned (note the indication of a neckline on the shorter figure).

At left stands an embracing couple. Facing left, the taller figure might be an older female. Her hair is short or drawn back into a bun. She looks down at the other figure and holds her visible hand on her companion's buttocks.

A tall, bearded old man in a gown stands facing right as he plays a large triangular harp with a bent right arm and a raised left one. He may be the bard of the title. His right foot shows beneath the hem of his garment. In this copy, his right ankle appears to bear a cuff—or perhaps even a shackle with a short length of chain to the right.

In the middle of the group, just right of the old man, stand two gowned children (distinctly shorter than their companions). The listening child to the left faces forward and looks up toward the bard or his harp. The child on the right faces right as he looks up toward the threesome to the right.

At right stand three young gowned females, at least the one on the left with short hair. They look toward and listen to the bard. The left-most of the three holds her arm, slightly bent, at her side and partly behind her back; the right-most faces left and bends her arm up to hold the arm of the middle figure. At their feet and facing away from the viewer kneels a fourth young female similarly dressed and coiffured. Her left arm is bent upward, with her left hand raised and fingers spread apart. She looks toward the threesome rather than at the bard.
Over the head of the figure at far right arches a palm-like frond.
A dark triangle of shadow extends below the figures from the lower right corner.
An old man, perhaps a bard, plays a large triangular harp that rests on the ground at his feet.
In this copy, the right ankle of the bard playing the harp appears to bear a cuff—or perhaps even a shackle with a short length of chain to the right.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 3-10 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the lower design.

component.illusobjdesc: Left of the "A" of the title is a large, spiky leaf. A vine right of lines 3-10 branches into three leaves on three long stems. A vine descends in the left margin of the text and into the lower design.

lg.l: Doubt is fled & clouds of reason.
They stumble all night over bones of the dead:
And feel they know not what but care;
And wish to lead others when they should be led

illustration.illusobjdesc: Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 10) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 13). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?). In front of the tree stands a figure, robed, apparently wearing a hat, and holding a staff—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 17), the glow-worm of the text in human form. He is one of four small human figures on the plate. The other three are in the area of the title: lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; sitting, perhaps reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and floating or flying, with arms raised horizontally, between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream." The animal life of the poem appears in similarly tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 4) beneath the "her" in line 9, another ant or beetle to the right of line 4, and beetles(?) (lines 19-20) flying right of lines 5 and 18. A bird, perhaps an eagle, unmentioned in the text, spreads its wings above "dream" in line 2.

component.illusobjdesc: In front of the tree in the bottom right corner stands a figure, robed, wearing a hat, and holding a staff in his(?) right hand, a lantern(?) in his left—probably the "watchman of the night" (line 17), the glow-worm of the text in human form.

There are three tiny figures in the area of the title: one lying, presumably sleeping, on the left stroke of the initial "A"; a second sitting, facing left, probably reading, in the "D" of "Dream"; and a third hovering or flying with arms raised horizontally between bits of vegetation beneath the "e" of "Dream."

The insect life of the poem appears in tiny forms in the margins: there could be an ant (the "Emmet" of line 4) beneath the "her" in line 9, another ant or beetle crawling to the right of line 4, a worm or caterpillar nestled in the lower right sprigs of the vegetation right of line 6, and perhaps winged beetles (lines 19-20) flying right of lines 5 and 18. The human figure lower right may be the anthropomorphic form of the "glow-worm" (line 15).
A bird, perhaps an eagle, soars just below the space between "A" and "Dream" in the title.

Several varieties of vegetation fill spaces around the text and between stanzas. The initial "A" in the title sprouts a plant-like structure on the left, while a loopy vine-like extension dangles all the way down the left margin. A further extension of this vine, or an independent vine, runs horizontally below the last stanza. The vegetation in the upper right margin—beside the "m" of "Dream" in the title—seems to be an arc of tasseled grass or grain that curves back over the title. Beneath it—opposite stanzas 1 and 2—are three or four clusters of flame-like leaves or tufts of grass. Below those are a bit of leafy vine (after line 10) and a branch or root of some sort (after line 13). In the lower right margin—opposite stanzas 4 and 5—is an odd tree(?).
The watchman in the lower right corner may be holding a staff in his right hand and a second object—perhaps a lantern—in his left. He seems to be wearing a hat.

lg.l: Once a dream did weave a shade,
That an Emmet lost it's way,
Where on grass methought I lay.
All heart-broke I heard her say.
O my children! do they cry,
Do they hear their father sigh,
Now they look abroad to see,
Now return and weep for me.
But I saw a glow-worm near;
Calls the watchman of the night.
I am set to light the ground,
While the beetle goes his round:

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young, curly-haired male shepherd in tights stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep. He holds a crook in his left hand; his shepherd's purse, or wallet, is visible near his right knee. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks forward and beside it another sheep lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees and a hill in the background. On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends. Three smaller birds soar to the right of the large bird. There may be two even smaller birds perched on the branch below and to the right of those in flight.

component.illusobjdesc: A young male shepherd with short, curly hair wears tights and stands in contrapposto, watching his grazing flock of sheep—perhaps looking at the sheep that lifts its head toward him. He holds a crook in his left hand; his purse is visible near his right knee. His arms are bent at the elbow, with his body facing forward but his head turned to the left.

A shepherd watches his grazing flock of sheep. In the foreground, one of the sheep looks straight ahead and beside it another sheep—possibly one of the "lambs" of line 6—lifts its head up, as if looking back at the shepherd. There is a ram just to the left of the shepherd's lower right leg. The rest of the grazing sheep appear to have their heads lowered to the ground, including several in the front and the one that may be a ram.

Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with blossoms near the bottom. The tree's longest branch extends almost to the left margin. There are more trees in the background.
Up the right margin beside the shepherd is a leafy tree encircled by a vine with lily-like blossoms near the bottom.
There are more trees and a hill in the background.

On the left a single bird with broad wings and long tail feathers ascends in the sky. Three much smaller birds soar to the right of the large one. There may be two even smaller birds perched on the branch below and to the right of those in flight.
The shepherd's purse is visible beside his right knee.
The shepherd holds a crook.

illustration.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

component.illusobjdesc: A vine with leaves branches off the "T" in "The" in the title.

lg.l: How sweet is the Shepherds sweet lot;
From the morn to the evening he strays;
He shall follow his sheep all the day
And his tongue shall be filled with praise.
For he hears the lambs innocent call,
And he hears the ewes tender reply.
He is watchful while they are in peace,
For they know when their Shepherd is nigh.

desc.objtitle: The Little Girl Lost , Object 29 (Bentley 34, Erdman 34, Keynes 34)

illustration.illusobjdesc: The design is focused on two human figures standing in an embrace under the arching branches of a tall, slender, vine-entwined willow-like tree in the right margin. A gowned female looks right as she points upward with her left arm and with her right arm embraces a young male, nude or possibly wearing tights. He looks at her and embraces her with at least his left arm. Left of her feet is a mound of vegetation—apparently a plant with one leaf visible, perhaps an anemone pulsatilla. To the left of the treetop a bird—with a long forked tail and wings spread—ascends. (The prominent but structurally independent vine that fills the left margin is classified here as interlinear decoration.)

component.illusobjdesc: The design is focused on two young human figures standing under a willow. Seen from behind with her left leg extended backward, a gowned female, with her hair pulled back (possibly into a bun), looks right as she points upward with her left arm and with her right arm embraces a young, curly-haired male. He would appear to be nude but might be wearing tights. Three fingers are clearly pictured on her raised left hand. He looks directly at her and embraces her with at least his left arm (note also slight evidence of his right arm just left of the female's back). They may be kissing.

Two figures embrace under the arching branches of a tall, slender, vine-entwined willow-like tree in the right margin. The vine—with numerous leaves and/or flowers—has two unusually extravagant tendrils to the left of the tree trunk. The lower one arches over the couple beneath and extends to the low plant.
To the left of the feet of the young female is a mound of vegetation—apparently a plant with one leaf visible, perhaps an anemone pulsatilla.
To the left of the treetop a bird—with a long forked tail and wings spread—ascends.

illustration.illusobjdesc: Independent of the rest of the design—hence here classified as interlinear decoration—an elaborate serpentine vine with leaves and flowers fills the left margin. A serpent-entwined tendril of the vine reinforces the division after the first two stanzas. Two birds, one descending and the other perching on the vine just below the other, are visible. A vine springs just right of the last letter in the title and dangles down past the upper reaches of the tree in the main design.

component.illusobjdesc: Independent of the rest of the design—hence classified here with interlinear decoration—an elaborate serpentine vine with leaves and flowers fills the left margin. A serpent-entwined tendril of the vine reinforces the division after the first two stanzas.
A vine springs just right of the last letter in the title and dangles down past the upper reaches of the tree in the main design.
Two birds, one descending and the other perching on the vine just below, are visible. Both have long tails.
A serpent is entwined with a tendril that reinforces the division after the first two stanzas. The serpent's head curves back to the left; its mouth is open and its tongue visible.

desc.objtitle: The Little Girl Found , Object 30 (Bentley 35, Erdman 35, Keynes 35)

illustration.illusobjdesc: A young(?), gowned female reclines on the ground under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. She may be Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (Object 29, line 21). Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background, and there appears to be other indeterminate vegetation in the far background. A slender tree or vine with a few leaves rises in the far left margin.

component.illusobjdesc: Under trees, a young(?) gowned female—perhaps identical with her unidentified counterpart on the previous object or perhaps Lyca, "Lost in desart [i.e., wilderness] wild" (Object 29, line 21)—reclines with her legs together and her weight resting on her braced right arm, her bent left arm folded across her body. Her hair is long, with a few locks(?) visible above her left shoulder. Her left foot is exposed. She looks upward to the right.

A female reclines on the ground under two large trees that frame the design on the left and right. Three other large trees, closely spaced, are visible in the center background, and there appears to be other indeterminate vegetation in the far background. The tree on the left has a bare branch that extends vertically up the margin, but its lower branches might be leafy, as are the branches of the other trees in the design. A thin, straight vine with leaves grows between the left margin and the large tree.

illustration.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 1) or the "lioness" (line 9) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost," stands on the ground beneath an arching tree. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal.

component.illusobjdesc: One of the "tygers" (line 1) or the "lioness" (line 9) mentioned in the last stanza of the companion poem, "The Little Girl Lost," stands on the ground beneath a tree. Its head is turned to the right and raised, echoing the position of the female in the design above.
A lion or tiger stands beneath an arching tree, bare except for one or two leaves far left. There are tufts of grass and/or indeterminate vegetation behind the animal.

illustration.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together. This vine, with a very small break, appears to be the same as the one bearing leaves and flowers that descends in the left margin of the text. Alternatively, this marginal vine may be growing from the lower left corner of the plate.

component.illusobjdesc: The initial letters "T" and "L" of the first two words of the title have vine-like loopy extensions linking them together. This vine, with a very small break, appears to be the same as the one bearing leaves and flowers that descends in the left margin of the text. Alternatively, this marginal vine may be growing from the lower left corner of the plate.

lg.l: And dream they see their child

illustration.illusobjdesc: On grass at the foot of the entwined trunks of two leafy trees (in turn entwined by leafy vines) in the right margin and near a pair of vines or a sapling and a vine in the left margin, a lion (right) lies close beside a seated infant while a lioness (left) or, less likely, a tiger (both mentioned in the text) lies with a nude infant sitting on her back. A nude female child stands beside them, holding the infant's arm, while a nude young(?) female lies sleeping(?) in front of them. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 8-30) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 22). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child, / Among tygers wild" (lines 33-34).

component.illusobjdesc: A curly-haired nude infant or child sits leaning on a lion and looks right toward it. The child's right hand rests on or holds the lion's right front leg. Although the child's body faces forward, his shoulders and head are twisted to the right.

A nude, short-haired infant or child, perhaps male, sits on the back of a lioness or tiger. His body faces left toward the front of the animal, and he reaches forward with his right hand as if to hold the animal by its head; but the infant reaches back with the left hand to hold the arm of a girl behind them.

A nude female child with long hair leans left toward an infant or child sitting on a lioness or tiger. With her left hand she reaches across her body to hold the left arm of the infant while her right hand seems to rest on the rear end of the animal. She looks down at the animal; her legs might be crossed at the ankles.

A young(?) nude female lies sleeping(?) on her left side facing away from the viewer with her head to the left and her right leg extended along the ground (left leg not pictured in this copy). Her upper body is twisted to face the ground and her arms are wrapped around her head. She may be Lyca, "the maid" who "lies asleep" in the "palace" (lines 8-30) of the royal lion who turns into a "spirit arm'd in gold" (line 22). Lyca's parents see their "sleeping child, / Among tygers wild" (lines 33-34).
On the left a lioness or, less likely, a tiger lies with its body facing left, its head twisted around to look right toward the child on its back.
A lion with a mane lies facing forward with its front paws extended as an infant or child sits next to it.
The entwined trunks of two large and leafy trees occupy the right margin. Small branches and leaves spring from both, although perhaps we are to imagine that these grow from an intertwined vine.
A pair of vines, one with loops, or a leafless sapling entwined by a leafy vine occupies the left margin.
